answer_html: \(\lim_{n \to \infty} (-1)^n \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)\) exists and equals 0 as well.

question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
First, note that

\[\begin{aligned} -\sin\left(\frac1{n}\right) \leq (-1)^n \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right) \leq \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)\end{aligned}\]

Further, since

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac1{n} = 0\end{aligned}\]

and \(\displaystyle \sin x\) is continuous at 0,

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \to \infty} \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right) = \sin\left(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac1{n}\right) = \sin(0) = 0\end{aligned}\]

Similarly,

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \to \infty} -\sin\left(\frac1{n}\right) = -0 = 0.\end{aligned}\]

By the squeeze theorem,

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \to \infty} (-1)^n \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)\end{aligned}\]

exists and equals 0 as well.

The alternating series test says that

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^n a_n\end{aligned}\]

converges if an is monotonically decreasing. In our case, \(a_n = \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)\), and since \(\frac1{n}\) monotonically decreases as n increases, and sin(x) is a monotone function for x in [0,1] we find that indeed \(a_n = \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)\) is monotonically decreasing. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^n a_n\end{aligned}\]

converges. But the question didn’t ask if the series converges, but if the sequence {(-1)n an} converges. This, however, follow as well because if a series \(\sum_{n=1}^\infty b_n\) converges, then the sequence {bn} must converge to zero, that is

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} b_n = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} (-1)^n \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)\end{aligned}\]

Hence, \((-1)^n \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)\) converges to 0.
